newsitem.title: SPAIN: FOCUS-Telefonica to name U.S. partner soon.
newsitem.headline: FOCUS-Telefonica to name U.S. partner soon.

text.p: Spain's Telefonica de Espana, working feverishly to pick a U.S. partner, said on Thursday it still had to reach a decision on an alliance that could reshape the global telecommunications sector and vault Telefonica into the top league.
A spokesman for the recently privatised telecommunications company said the board had still not fixed what it wanted to do with its international alliances.
"It's true that the board met yesterday to study the issue of an international partner, but it wasn't the only subject and we haven't made any decision yet."

Telefonica is half-way through a self-imposed deadline of six weeks to make a decision. Analysts said the group was likely to press ahead swiftly, given the industry uproar prompted by news it was talking to firms outside its current alliance.
Telefonica said talks with various operators had intensifed and that it would probably make a decision in coming days, according to a statement from stock market commission CNMV.

Three weeks ago, Telefonica chairman Juan Villalonga said the group was in talks with the chairmen of MCI, British Telecom and Southwestern Bell Corp as well as with AT&T, with whom it has an alliance already.
Telefonica is attractive because it has extensive Latin American holdings through its international subsidiary TISA, which had sales last year of around 350 billion pesetas ($2.4 billion).

Villalonga intends to exploit this advantage to snatch a U.S. partner that will convert Telefonica -- once a state-run behemoth that took six months to install a phone -- into one of the top six leading international telecommunications groups.
Telefonica currently forms part of Unisource, a primarily European consortium directed by AT&T which groups Sweden's Telia, Swiss Telecom and Koninklijke PTT Nederland of the Netherlands.
But analysts believe Telefonica is now favouring MCI over AT&T, which would mean a break with Unisource and would probably force other operators to rejuggle partnerships.
Both MCI and AT&T would provide Telefonica with an inroad into the enormous U.S. market, but MCI's powerful European partner BT may persuade Telefonica in its favour.
"MCI would give Telefonica access to the U.S. where it is a key operator. But AT&T could also provide that access," a Madrid-based analyst said.
"But this is not just about U.S. access, Telefonica's talks imply it is reviewing its entire system of alliances...to allow them to expand in the future," he added.

MCI is hooked up with AT&T's key rival, BT. Concert, their planned merger, could offer Telefonica better European growth than Unisource, which analysts say has not provided Telefonica with huge benefits.

"Doing an alliance with MCI would also mean one with BT, which is the most competitive group at the moment. It would also remove one of Telefonica's key European rivals," another Madrid-based analyst said. ($ = 145.4 Spanish Pesetas)
